Allan Halme wrote:

> This is great -- but what if we have a concrete class implementing
> multiple interfaces?

Well, that wasn't the problem I was trying to solve! :)

Let's look at the simplest case: Foo implements A, B. It turns out that 
this is very simple: have one test suite (TestCase class) per interface.

1. FooAContractTest extends ATestCase verifies that Foo implements A's 
contract correctly.

2. FooBContractTest extends BTestCase verifies that Foo implements B's 
contract correctly.

3. FooTest, if necessary, verifies Foo's behavior beyond the contracts 
of A and B.

So, in the more complicated case:

> Foo extends BImpl implements B implements C
> BImpl extends AImpl implements A

1. Start with three different Abstract Test Cases for the contract tests 
for A, B, C: ATestCase, BTestCase, CTestCase.

2. AImplTest extends ATestCase.

3. BImplAContractTest extends AImplTest if you can, and ATestCase if you 
can't. (BImpl might change an implementation detail of an A method, but 
respect the weaker A contract.)

4. BImplBContractTest extends BTestCase.

5. BImplCContractTest extends CTestCase.

6. FooTest, if necessary, verifies Foo's behavior beyond the contracts 
of A, B and C.

The key thing to remember is that one test suite per production class is 
only a starting point heuristic, and not a requirement of JUnit.
